subject: RE: [junit] written recommendation of super.setUp/tearDown ?
msgSnippet: ... Allan Halme ... I don t know, but it s really easy to do:  use annotations to pick setUp() and tearDown() methods instead of relying on their name.  Not
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Allan Halme

> Do we know whether JUnit 4 will be resolving this "design
> smell", i.e. will it no longer require subclasses of TestCase
> to explicitly remember to call super.setUp and super.tearDown() ?

I don't know, but it's really easy to do: use annotations to pick setUp()
and tearDown() methods instead of relying on their name. Not only does it
solve this problem, it also lets you name these methods any way you want and
even have several of them (not sure it's really useful, but why not?).

That's what TestNG does:

@Configuration(beforeTestMethod = true)
void thisIsASetUpMethod() { ... }

@Configuration(afterTestMethod = true)
void thisIsATearDownMethod() { ... }

> One other thing that has to be remembered, that I always
> initially forget, is that--at least in my test
> fixtures--you'll want to call super.setUp() _first_ in your
> subclass's overriding method, but you'll want to call
> super.tearDown() correspondingly _last_ in its overriding method ...

True. Another reason why it's a design smell.
